channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: The Russian journalist Dmitri Muratov — whose paper suspended publication in late March, saying Russia’s press laws made it impossible to truthfully cover the war in Ukraine — will be auctioning his Nobel Peace Prize medal to benefit Ukrainian refugees. https://t.co/VZCVkZxmz1

Elon Musk told SpaceX and Tesla employees that they were required to “spend a minimum of 40 hours in the office per week.” Those who did not do so would be fired, he wrote in a memo. https://t.co/eOwVV5UIGp https://t.co/pHzcnIDHm1

Sarah Palin lost her bid for a new trial in her libel case against The New York Times. A judge ruled that she had failed to produce “even a speck” of evidence to prove the newspaper had defamed her in a 2017 editorial. https://t.co/4Jx0iqVPHE
“The Wire” premiered 20 years ago, in June 2002. The creators David Simon and Ed Burns discussed why it has only become more relevant — and why it would never be made today. https://t.co/wTtbsQd3X4

The Russian military, demoralized after three months of war, is still facing morale and other problems, seven weeks after the Kremlin sent a new commander to oversee a refocused invasion, American officials say. https://t.co/WICddQYBem

In Opinion
"America’s goal is straightforward," President Biden writes in a guest essay. "We want to see a democratic, independent, sovereign and prosperous Ukraine with the means to deter and defend itself against further aggression." https://t.co/c2AM54y140
Rafael Nadal beat Novak Djokovic in four sets to reach the French Open semifinals in a thrilling addition to their long rivalry. https://t.co/qgwhrhBA8X

Sarah Palin lost her bid for a new trial in her libel case against The New York Times. A judge ruled that she had failed to produce “even a speck” of evidence to prove the newspaper had defamed her in a 2017 editorial. https://t.co/fCeia4GPZo

Adm. Linda L. Fagan will shatter one of the last glass ceilings in the military on Wednesday when she takes the oath as commandant of the Coast Guard and becomes the first female officer to lead a branch of the U.S. armed forces. https://t.co/eUh9ihXPcl

Despite widespread vaccination among older adults, the Omicron wave killed seniors in the U.S. at much higher rates per capita than Delta, preying on long delays since their last shots and showing the importance of boosters as campaigns nationwide wane. https://t.co/Qg1RjeczuI https://t.co/qq2z1QNZmP

Breaking News: Michael Sussmann​​, a lawyer with Democratic ties who flagged possible links between Donald Trump and Russia in 2016, was acquitted on a charge of lying to the FBI. https://t.co/n6Ajys4kVF

Russian mercenaries helped soldiers in the West African nation of Mali carry out a massacre, executing hundreds of civilians, witnesses and others said. Using satellite imagery, The New York Times identified the sites of at least two mass graves. https://t.co/KREIzPnRLg

Trump-era policies have left the U.S. far behind its peers in the race to combat climate change, according to a new report.
Only Denmark and Britain were on sustainable paths to reach net-zero by 2050, the study found. https://t.co/BXhXUPcx22

"We need to bring them home."
The wives and sisters of Ukrainian servicemen who were ordered to surrender to Russian forces at the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol issued an urgent appeal to Ukrainian authorities and to the world to free their loved ones. https://t.co/l0dbs3nghu

The Ukrainian band that won Eurovision, Kalush Orchestra, put its trophy and a pink bucket hat worn by its lead singer up for auction to help supply drones to the Ukrainian army.
The items netted more than $1.2 million, the band’s spokeswoman said. https://t.co/Min2VQalVF
Canada would require most owners of “military-style assault weapons” to turn them over under a new proposed bill that is likely to pass. https://t.co/YAPnMFDTbr https://t.co/zXhymQL4Bi
Anger over two horrific mass shootings in Texas and New York has stirred a debate over whether releasing graphic images of gun violence would lead to better policy. https://t.co/ubQHAnhIEA
A Russian warplane crashed into a house in Ukraine. The family lived, almost miraculously. A few blocks away, things were different. https://t.co/o4Kd6Yqaur https://t.co/qzkXEFgbqk
Peter Navarro, a former aide to Donald Trump, said he received a grand jury subpoena in relation to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol. https://t.co/uuWRBDeP9e

A century-old building under renovation in the Bronx has become one of the deadliest construction sites in New York City in almost two decades. But the consequences have been negligible and inspectors have exacted just $28,864 in fines. https://t.co/SYWLQ8ubzh
Canada would require most owners of “military-style assault weapons” to turn them over under a new proposed bill that is likely to pass. https://t.co/5ZHMRygSB0

In the days after the 2020 election, Cleta Mitchell, a Republican lawyer, became a central figure in the failed scheme to overturn Donald Trump's loss. Now she is recruiting and helping train election conspiracists to monitor voting around the U.S. https://t.co/fDyNxLnORO

A doctor in Southern California who sold “Covid-19 treatment packs” during the first weeks of the coronavirus pandemic was sentenced late last week to prison, prosecutors said. https://t.co/iUPjvdvUuc

A man who faked a disability to get close to the Mona Lisa in a wheelchair stood up and smeared a pastry on its glass case on Sunday, according to the Louvre museum in Paris. The man, who a witness said had “dressed as an old lady,” was taken into custody. https://t.co/5PlMzixYk4
Breaking News: The EU is poised to reach a deal on a Russian oil ban, its most significant move to punish Moscow for its invasion of Ukraine. It gave concessions to Hungary. https://t.co/Frn7zhK1ld

Protesters pleaded for a full embargo on Russian energy in front of the European Council’s headquarters in Brussels, hours before European leaders were set to begin a summit on Ukraine. https://t.co/acWEwKLZcj https://t.co/1Qe8Qeycrj

This cafe is devoted to remembering those killed in Rodrigo Duterte’s bloody war on drugs.
Served along with the coffee are personal stories from the staff, who are relatives of the victims of the extrajudicial killings in the Philippines. https://t.co/bJ5tH0PpJh https://t.co/Jzlhf6hDKP

For all of 10 days, the racist massacre in Buffalo was the year’s deadliest mass shooting. It left the family of one victim, Celestine Chaney, mourning the loss of a mother, sister, grandparent and best friend. https://t.co/JRoxTbcYzM

President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s block on NATO membership for Sweden and Finland is likely to be managed, but has renewed questions about whether the alliance might be better off without Turkey. https://t.co/Xl6PVbRE8W

Television turned the celebrity trial into a 24-hour tabloid spectacle. With the defamation trial between Johnny Depp and Amber Heard, our critic @amandahess writes, social media has made it into a sport. https://t.co/iZ1soRy1Ki

When families learned that a gunman had entered Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, a brutal wait began. Police on the scene did not stop the gunman for well over an hour.
The New York Times has put together an account of each of those 78 minutes. https://t.co/sj95rZc8T7

“Everything Everywhere All at Once” is multiverse galaxy-brain head trip, but it’s also a bittersweet domestic drama, a marital comedy and a story of immigrant striving, our critic writes. https://t.co/56j907MHTh

Paul Pelosi, the husband of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, was charged with misdemeanor driving under the influence of alcohol in Napa County, Calif., on Saturday night.
Bail for Mr. Pelosi, 82, was set at $5,000. Speaker Pelosi was not with him. https://t.co/qWeuHh5tlV

Ukrainian soldiers, seeking to spread Russian forces thin, launched a counteroffensive on Sunday in Kherson, the key southern city that Moscow considered so securely under its thumb that it had introduced the ruble. https://t.co/hkjuaFtXwi

"Top Gun: Maverick" landed a triumphant opening weekend with estimated ticket sales of $151 million in North America. Analysts said it was a defining moment for the film industry’s box office recovery from the long pandemic slump. https://t.co/DbFzuQtZeP

It's time for the most striking sunsets of the year in New York City — Manhattanhenge is upon us.
You’ll get four chances to see it, starting on Sunday night. Here's what you need to know. https://t.co/bCdLfDO22J https://t.co/Z8JxaMECD3

Children’s learning loss in the pandemic isn’t just in reading and math. It’s also in social and emotional skills. In a New York Times survey of 362 school counselors across the U.S., they said students are behind in abilities to learn, cope and relate. https://t.co/CkyUNZ8q0e https://t.co/b3JnHMFdJv

President Biden on Sunday wiped away a tear while embracing survivors of the massacre at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas. It was his second such trip in nearly two weeks to mourn with families suffering from a mass shooting. https://t.co/tC7tiCDpjm https://t.co/UH4njxquim

President Volodymyr Zelensky visited frontline troops in northeastern Ukraine, marking a success for troops who pushed Russian forces back from the outskirts of the country’s second-largest city, after months of shelling that killed many civilians. https://t.co/LGfAdGzsur https://t.co/XhKgHgEEZ4

As polls opened on Sunday in Bogotá, Colombia’s capital, one name could be heard over and over in a working-class neighborhood: Gustavo Petro, the rebel-turned-politician who is making a bid to become the first leftist president in the nation's history. https://t.co/hePch9sL65

President Biden and First Lady Jill Biden visited a memorial at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas on Sunday. They stopped in front of life-size photos of the shooting victims, placing their hands on each photo and reading their names. https://t.co/56Pszn9Eqb https://t.co/Hz3bjFLU4g
Breaking News: The U.S. Justice Department said it would investigate the law enforcement response to the school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, that left 21 people dead. https://t.co/Dfh2Y5vb4q

President Biden will be attending Mass and meeting with grieving family members in Uvalde, Texas today.
Follow our updates: https://t.co/CVbta19JGM https://t.co/EEjwQPir3m

Just 12 days after mourning with families of victims of a mass shooting in Buffalo, President Biden will travel to Uvalde, Texas on Sunday to console a community suffering from yet another massacre of young children. https://t.co/lVLVoEKPCy

When families learned a gunman had entered an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, a brutal wait began. Police did not stop him for over an hour.
This is an account of each of those 78 minutes — told by videos, witness statements and accounts of 911 calls. https://t.co/cCrEh6c7pu

Every mass shooting requires unique paths of mourning. The family of Celestine Chaney — one of the 10 people killed in the Buffalo supermarket attack — bid farewell to a mother, sister, grandparent and best friend. https://t.co/kWQOQWnjGv https://t.co/nMvn1OHUk4

Those close to Brittney Griner pursued a strategy of silence after the WNBA star's detention in Russia in February, hoping to avoid politicizing her case. Now they are amping up public pressure — with some of it aimed at President Biden. https://t.co/ocubpoBXBZ

There is a wealth of evidence that the 18-year-old Uvalde gunman teased his plans weeks before the attack. One of his co-workers at a Wendy’s said he frequently snapped at other employees, and that they took to calling him names including "school shooter." https://t.co/zDtAeMkDRP

A new law in Texas bans state agencies from working with a firm that "discriminates" against gun companies or individuals in the gun industry. As large companies grapple with how to respond to tragedies, laws like this one make it harder to take a stance. https://t.co/nAqN314AqN

The Texas school shooting has put a national spotlight on Daniel Defense and its aggressive, boundary-pushing style of weapons marketing. The company's sales have soared, in part because of successful targeting of young customers like the Uvalde gunman. https://t.co/XngD8spsOX
